missingTests.title: Finish the tests first
missingTests.subtitle: Profession fit needs your Imposed, Surface, and Innate persona results.

header.subtitle: Matching your drive structure to real-world job demands

about.title: About this report
about.body: This report simulates fit using your (1) surface persona, (2) innate persona, (3) competence/self-interest, and (4) instrumentation routes. You can view match in two ways: Aspired Job Match (uses SurfaceAdjustedAspired) and Job Match (uses SurfaceAdjusted). Both views consider energy drain. Aspired match also reflects what you value and what you’re trying to grow into—so your “best fits” can shift depending on which lens you use.
about.note: Quick note: these patterns change over time. It’s worth re-checking every so often.

majors.title: Pick up to 10 occupational majors you’re considering.
majors.emptyBody: Once you select majors, you’ll get the top 10 fits plus a detailed breakdown you can click into.

mode.title: How do you want to view match?

top10.title: Top 10 Best Fits
top10.subtitle: {count} subtypes
top10.scoreNote: Match score is 0–5, where 5 is the strongest match.

active.interpretationBody: This view ranks match using {effective}. We compute the difference by subtracting the job’s demand from your effective surface profile. Drives shown in red are where you’re below the job’s demand (deficits), and drives shown in green are where you’re above it (surpluses).

noSelection.title: No selection yet
noSelection.body: Pick a profession subtype on the left to see the full breakdown.

footer.body: If a job shows a lower match score, it doesn’t automatically mean “don’t do it.” Usually it means (1) you’ll want an environment that supports your deficit drives, and (2) it helps to reduce energy drains so your effort goes further.
footer.drainCta: View your Energy Drain and Adaptation Analysis →

driveDef.Exploration: Curiosity + variety—wanting new ideas, experiences, and possibilities.
driveDef.Achievement: Goal drive—pushing to accomplish, improve, and master challenges.
driveDef.Dominance: Direction + control—wanting influence, leadership, and decision power.
driveDef.Pleasure: Comfort + enjoyment—seeking fun, ease, and immediate rewards.
driveDef.Care: Nurture drive—protecting, supporting, and emotionally holding others.
driveDef.Affiliation: Belonging drive—connection, teamwork, and being part of a group.
driveDef.Value: Principles drive—staying aligned with what feels right and meaningful.
